claim: Fig 1 presents a PRISMA flow diagram indicating the studies retrieved for the review, screening, and assessment of eligibility (S1 Table).
title: Fig 1. Systematic search according to the PRISMA statement methodology.

claim:
General characteristics of psychodrama studies
As can be seen in Fig 2, the majority of the PD research publications were from Turkey (n = 12, 39%), with the next largest groups from Italy (n = 4, 13%) and Israel (n = 3, 10%), and USA (n = 3, 10%).
title: Fig 2. Frequency of included publications by country.

claim: Regarding client populations and primary outcomes, as can be seen in Fig 3, the majority of the PD research publications dealt with youth at risk (n = 10, 32%), followed by students (n = 4, 13%), and adults with different mental health conditions (n = 4, 13%).
title: Fig 3. Primary outcomes.
caption: Frequency of primary outcomes. SWB = subjective wellbeing, GSF = general symptoms and functioning, BP = behavioral problems.

claim: As also seen in Fig 3, other primary outcomes included subjective well-being, smoking cessation, burnout, hopelessness, loneliness, sense of coherence, public stigma, self-stigma, self-esteem, self-efficacy, and self-concept.
title: Fig 3. Primary outcomes.
caption: Frequency of primary outcomes. SWB = subjective wellbeing, GSF = general symptoms and functioning, BP = behavioral problems.

claim: A summary of the risk of bias analysis is presented in Table 5 and the proportion of studies for each of the six potential sources of bias is presented in Fig 4.
title: Fig 4. Proportion of studies for each of the six potential sources of bias.

claim: As can be seen in Fig 2, the majority of the PD research publications were from Turkey (n = 12, 39%), with the next largest groups from Italy (n = 4, 13%) and Israel (n = 3, 10%), and USA (n = 3, 10%).
title: Fig 2. Frequency of included publications by country.
